content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail shows multiple fragments of tissue, consistent with a lymph node dissection from a colorectal cancer resection. I can identify at least seven separate pieces of tissue that appear to be lymph nodes, characterized by their dense purple (lymphoid) centers and surrounding pink (adipose) tissue. The nodes vary in size. The goal would be to meticulously examine each lymph node for the presence of metastatic carcinoma.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The pathologist has zoomed into the periphery of the largest lymph node located in the upper left corner of the slide. This specific area is of interest because of the noticeable green substance at the tissue edge. This is most likely tattoo ink, which is used during endoscopy to mark the location of the tumor for subsequent surgery and pathological examination. It is crucial to examine the tissue adjacent to the ink to ensure that it isn't obscuring any metastatic tumor cells, which can sometimes be found in the subcapsular sinus or extending into the surrounding fat (extranodal extension). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area to begin the systematic examination of the lymph nodes for metastasis. This is the largest and most superior-left lymph node on the slide. The zoom is targeted towards the periphery of the node, near the capsule. This is a high-yield area to examine, as metastatic tumor cells often first arrive and deposit in the subcapsular sinus, which is located just under the capsule. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my procedure is to examine every single piece of tissue submitted as a lymph node. The area highlighted by the green box is clearly one of these potential lymph nodes. I would zoom into this area as part of my systematic screening process. The goal is to assess the node's architecture and cytology at high magnification to definitively rule in or rule out the presence of metastatic tumor cells, which cannot be done at the low magnification of the thumbnail view. This appears to be the third lymph node-like structure from the top left that I would examine. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node on the slide. The green box is located on one of the larger lymph nodes in the lower-left quadrant. At low power, the periphery of this node, specifically in the boxed area, appears slightly irregular and possibly contains some darker pigment or artifact. I am zooming in to this region to assess the capsule and the subcapsular sinus, which are common initial sites for metastatic tumor cells to lodge. I need to get a closer look at the cellular architecture to determine if the irregularity is due to metastatic carcinoma, a benign reactive process, or artifact. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my standard procedure is to meticulously examine every single piece of tissue on the slide to ensure no potential metastasis is missed. The highlighted area contains a small, elongated fragment of basophilic tissue, which is suspicious for being a lymph node or a fragment of one. Although small, it must be carefully evaluated at high power for the presence of isolated tumor cells or micrometastasis, which can be prognostically significant. This is part of a systematic, comprehensive review of all submitted tissue. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the standard of care requires a thorough examination of every lymph node submitted for staging. The green box is placed on one of the smaller lymph nodes located on the right side of the slide. I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic review of all tissue fragments. Even small nodes can contain metastatic deposits (micrometastases or isolated tumor cells), so each one must be carefully evaluated at high magnification to rule out the presence of malignant cells. This is a routine step in the diagnostic workflow for cancer staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the task is to systematically evaluate every lymph node for evidence of cancer spread. This specific area is within one of the larger lymph nodes on the slide (the fourth largest, located on the mid-left). I would zoom into this area as part of a comprehensive examination of this particular node, panning across its entire surface at high magnification to meticulously search for any atypical cells, abnormal glands, or architectural effacement that would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node on the slide. The green box is placed over one of the discrete lymph nodes located in the bottom right of the image. It is crucial to examine each node at high power to search for metastatic deposits. I would zoom in to assess the overall architecture, check the subcapsular sinus (a common site for early metastases), and scrutinize the cellular population for any atypical, non-lymphoid cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows fibroadipose tissue with bundles of smooth muscle. There are prominent features including large collections of red blood cells (hemorrhage) and deposits of a coarse, dark green, granular pigment consistent with tattoo ink. Some of this pigment appears to be within macrophages. There are no atypical glandular structures or nests of malignant cells visible in this field. My impression of this specific area is benign pericapsular soft tissue with hemorrhage and tattoo pigment deposition. There is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in this view.
This is ROI 2. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I can clearly see the edge of the lymph node. The majority of the field consists of dense, small, dark lymphocytes, which are normal for a lymph node. However, there are also distinct clusters of abnormal cells. These cells are larger, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and large, irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei. They are arranged in poorly formed glandular structures. These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing a clear metastatic deposit.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a section of a lymph node. It is composed of a dense, diffuse population of lymphocytes (small, dark purple cells). The node is surrounded by a fibrous capsule and perinodal adipose tissue (fat). I am specifically looking for atypical epithelial cells, either in clusters or forming glands, which would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma from a colorectal primary. In this particular field of view, I do not see any convincing evidence of metastatic carcinoma. The cellular population appears to be composed of normal lymphoid elements. My impression is that this is a benign (reactive) lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the parenchyma of a lymph node, composed of dense sheets of small lymphocytes. There are follicular structures, some with reactive germinal centers, indicating a benign reactive state. Along the lower edge of the tissue, there is a prominent deposit of black, granular pigment. This is anthracotic pigment (carbon), a common and benign finding in mesenteric lymph nodes, likely within macrophages in the sinus. I do not see any definite evidence of metastatic carcinoma in this field; there are no atypical glands, nests of malignant cells, or significant desmoplastic stromal reaction. My impression for this specific field is a reactive lymph node with anthracosis. I would proceed to examine the remainder of this node and all other nodes on the slide.
This is ROI 5. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see a fragment of lymphoid tissue composed of a dense population of small, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. This is consistent with the cortex or paracortex of a lymph node. Adjacent to the lymphoid tissue, there is some pink fibrous connective tissue and adipose tissue. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or signet ring cells that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific area is that it is a fragment of a benign (negative) lymph node.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a dense, monotonous population of small, round cells with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. The overall architecture is consistent with normal lymphoid parenchyma. I do not see any atypical cells, such as large cells with irregular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and eosinophilic cytoplasm, nor do I see any glandular structures or mucin pools that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma from a colorectal primary. My impression of this specific field of view is that it shows a benign lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see dense lymphoid tissue composed of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. There are preserved architectural features, including lymphoid follicles and interfollicular areas. I can also identify some small blood vessels, including a prominent arteriole. Crucially, I do not see any evidence of metastatic carcinoma, such as clusters of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or extensive necrosis. My impression of this specific field of view is that it represents a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the interface between a lymph node (left) and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue (right). The lymph node is densely packed with small, round lymphocytes with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. I can see the fibrous capsule separating the lymphoid tissue from the fat. I do not observe any atypical cell clusters, glandular formations, or large cells with prominent nucleoli that would be indicative of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is that it represents a benign/reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
